hints.label: def-bregman-divergence
hints.title: Bregman Divergence
hints.content:
2713: :label: def-bregman-divergence
2714: 
2715: For a strictly convex function $\phi: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$, the **Bregman divergence** is:
2716: 
2717: $$
2718: D_\phi(x \| y) := \phi(x) - \phi(y) - \langle \nabla \phi(y), x - y \rangle
2719: $$
2720: 
2721: This measures the difference between $\phi(x)$ and its first-order Taylor approximation around $y$.
hints.raw_directive:
2710: The Weinhold metric has a deep connection to information geometry through Bregman divergences.

hints.label: prop-weinhold-bregman
hints.title: Weinhold Metric as Bregman Hessian
hints.content:
2727: :label: prop-weinhold-bregman
2728: 
2729: The Weinhold metric is the Hessian of the Bregman generating function:
2730: 
2731: $$
2732: g_W^{ij} = \frac{\partial^2 U}{\partial S^i \partial S^j}
2733: $$
2734: 
2735: corresponds to the Bregman divergence:
2736: 
2737: $$
2738: D_U(S \| S_0) = U(S) - U(S_0) - \sum_i \frac{\partial U}{\partial S^i}\Big|_{S_0} (S^i - S_0^i)
2739: $$
hints.raw_directive:
2724: :::
2725: 
2726: :::{prf:proposition} Weinhold Metric as Bregman Hessian
2727: :label: prop-weinhold-bregman
2728: 
2729: The Weinhold metric is the Hessian of the Bregman generating function:
2730: 
2731: $$
2732: g_W^{ij} = \frac{\partial^2 U}{\partial S^i \partial S^j}
2733: $$
2734: 
2735: corresponds to the Bregman divergence:
2736: 
2737: $$
2738: D_U(S \| S_0) = U(S) - U(S_0) - \sum_i \frac{\partial U}{\partial S^i}\Big|_{S_0} (S^i - S_0^i)
2739: $$
2740:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-35
hints.content:
2744: :::{prf:proof}
2745: 
2746: **Step 1**: Expand $D_U(S \| S_0)$ to second order.
2747: 
2748: $$
2749: \begin{align}
2750: D_U(S \| S_0) &= U(S) - U(S_0) - \nabla U(S_0) \cdot (S - S_0) \\
2751: &= \frac{1}{2}(S - S_0)^T \cdot \nabla^2 U(S_0) \cdot (S - S_0) + O(|S - S_0|^3)
2752: \end{align}
2753: $$
2754: 
2755: **Step 2**: Identify the metric.
2756: 
2757: The Hessian $\nabla^2 U = g_W$ is the metric tensor. Therefore, for infinitesimal separations:
2758: 
2759: $$
2760: D_U(S \| S_0) \approx \frac{1}{2} ds^2
2761: $$
2762: 
2763: where $ds^2 = g_W^{ij} dS^i dS^j$ is the line element of the Weinhold metric.
2764: 
2765: **Step 3**: Connection to thermodynamics.

hints.title: Comparison to Fisher Information
hints.content:
2771: :class: note
2772: 
2773: **Ruppeiner metric**: Derived from Fisher information, inherently tied to statistical fluctuations
2774: - Natural for stochastic systems (Fragile Gas!)
2775: - Connects to KL-divergence rate
2776: 
2777: **Weinhold metric**: Derived from Bregman divergence, tied to energy fluctuations
2778: - Natural for deterministic thermodynamics
2779: - Connects to irreversible work
